definitions: person who works to protect natural environments from destruction or pollution
examples: The environmentalist organized a protest against the new oil pipeline
Many environmentalists are calling for stricter regulations on carbon emissions

definitions: act of forming a mental picture of something that does not yet exist
examples: The architect spent hours envisioning the new city center design
Strategic planning requires envisioning multiple possible future scenarios

definitions: official representative sent by a government on a special diplomatic mission
examples: The president sent a special envoy to negotiate the peace treaty
The envoy delivered an urgent message from the prime minister

definitions: painful feeling of wanting what another person has or wishing their advantages
examples: Her success filled him with envy and resentment
Envy can destroy even the strongest friendships over time

definitions: protein molecule that speeds up chemical reactions in living organisms without being consumed
examples: Digestive enzymes break down food into smaller molecules
The lab tested the enzyme activity at different temperature levels

definitions: indefinitely long period of time, especially in geology spanning millions of years
examples: Dinosaurs ruled the Earth for eons before their extinction
It felt like eons had passed since they last spoke

definitions: things that exist or are used for only a short time, especially printed materials
examples: The museum collected ephemera like concert tickets and vintage postcards
Digital ephemera includes temporary social media posts and stories

definitions: long poem telling of heroic deeds and adventures
something remarkably great in size or scope
examples: Homer's Iliad is considered one of the greatest epics in literature
The ancient epic tells the story of a hero's journey
Their cross-country road trip turned into an epic adventure
The movie featured epic battle scenes with thousands of extras

definitions: point on Earth's surface directly above where an earthquake originates
central point of something, especially of an activity or crisis
examples: The earthquake's epicenter was located fifty miles from the city
Seismologists quickly determined the epicenter of the major tremor
Silicon Valley became the epicenter of technological innovation
The small town was the epicenter of the political scandal

definitions: point on Earth's surface directly above where an earthquake originates
central point of something, especially of an activity or crisis
examples: The earthquake's epicentre was located fifty miles from the city
Seismologists quickly determined the epicentre of the major tremor
London became the epicentre of the financial crisis
The small town was the epicentre of the political scandal

definitions: person devoted to sensual enjoyment, especially from fine food and drink
examples: The epicurean savored every bite of the gourmet meal
His epicurean lifestyle included weekly visits to exclusive restaurants

definitions: widespread occurrence of infectious disease in a community at a particular time
examples: The flu epidemic forced many schools to close temporarily
Health officials worked to contain the epidemic before it spread further

definitions: scientist who studies how diseases spread and can be controlled in populations
examples: The epidemiologist tracked the virus transmission patterns across the region
Epidemiologists played a crucial role during the pandemic response

definitions: branch of medicine dealing with incidence, distribution, and control of diseases in populations
examples: She earned her doctorate in epidemiology from Johns Hopkins University
Epidemiology helps us understand how diseases spread through communities

definitions: injection of anesthetic into the space around the spinal nerves, especially during childbirth
examples: The mother requested an epidural to manage her labor pain
The anesthesiologist carefully administered the epidural before the surgery

definitions: short, clever statement expressing an idea in a witty or paradoxical way
examples: Oscar Wilde was famous for his brilliant epigrams about society
The book opened with an epigram about the nature of truth

definitions: short quotation at the beginning of a book or chapter
inscription on a building, statue, or coin
examples: The novel's epigraph perfectly captured the theme of loss
She chose a line from Shakespeare as the epigraph for her thesis
Archaeologists studied the ancient epigraph carved into the temple wall
The epigraph on the monument commemorated the fallen soldiers

definitions: neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance and loss of consciousness
examples: The doctor prescribed medication to control her epilepsy symptoms
Many people with epilepsy lead completely normal lives with proper treatment

definitions: person who has epilepsy, a condition causing recurrent seizures
examples: The epileptic wore a medical alert bracelet for emergencies
Support groups help epileptics manage their condition and reduce stigma

definitions: section at the end of a book or play serving as conclusion
examples: The epilogue revealed what happened to the characters years later
She added an epilogue to provide closure for the readers

definitions: hormone secreted by adrenal glands that increases heart rate and blood pressure during stress
examples: The doctor injected epinephrine to treat the severe allergic reaction
Epinephrine auto-injectors can save lives during anaphylactic shock

definitions: moment of sudden revelation or insight about something important
Christian festival celebrating the manifestation of Christ to the Gentiles
examples: She had an epiphany about her career while walking on the beach
His epiphany came when he realized money couldn't buy happiness
The church held special services to celebrate Epiphany in January
Epiphany marks the visit of the three wise men to Jesus

definitions: branch of philosophy concerned with the theory of knowledge, especially its methods and validity
examples: The philosophy course covered epistemology and the nature of truth
Epistemology asks fundamental questions about how we know what we know

definitions: formal or religious letter, especially one written by an apostle in the New Testament
examples: Paul's epistles form a significant part of the New Testament
The professor wrote lengthy epistles to his former students

definitions: phrase or words written in memory of a person who has died, especially on a tombstone
examples: The epitaph on her grave read 'Beloved Mother and Friend'
He spent weeks composing the perfect epitaph for his father

definitions: word or phrase expressing a quality or attribute of someone or something
abusive or contemptuous word or phrase
examples: Homer often used epithets like 'swift-footed Achilles' in his poems
The epithet 'the Great' was added to Alexander's name
The angry crowd hurled epithets at the controversial speaker
Using racial epithets is both hurtful and completely unacceptable

definitions: person or thing that perfectly represents a particular quality or type
examples: She was the epitome of grace under pressure
The old mansion was the epitome of Southern elegance

definitions: period of time in history marked by notable events or characteristics
division of geological time less than a period and greater than an age
examples: The Victorian epoch saw tremendous industrial and social changes
The invention of the internet marked the beginning of a new epoch
The Pleistocene epoch was characterized by repeated ice ages
Geologists study rock formations from different epochs

definitions: person after whom something is named, or the name itself derived from a person
examples: Alzheimer's disease is an eponym named after Dr. Alois Alzheimer
The word 'sandwich' is an eponym from the Earl of Sandwich

definitions: strong adhesive made from synthetic resins that hardens when mixed with a catalyst
examples: The craftsman used epoxy to bond the metal pieces together
Marine epoxy provides waterproof sealing for boat repairs

definitions: fifth letter of the Greek alphabet, often used in mathematics to represent a small quantity
examples: The mathematician used epsilon to denote an arbitrarily small positive number
In the equation, epsilon represents the margin of error

definitions: goal that makes the score equal in a game or match
electronic device that adjusts frequency response in audio systems
examples: The striker scored a dramatic equaliser in the final minutes
The home team desperately searched for an equaliser
The sound engineer adjusted the equaliser to enhance the bass
Modern car stereos include built-in equalisers for custom sound

definitions: act or process of making things equal or uniform in amount, value, or status
examples: The new policy aims for salary equalization across all departments
Equalization payments help balance resources between rich and poor regions

definitions: goal that makes the score equal in a game or match
electronic device that adjusts frequency response in audio systems
examples: The striker scored a dramatic equalizer in the final minutes
The home team desperately searched for an equalizer
The sound engineer adjusted the equalizer to enhance the bass
Modern car stereos include built-in equalizers for custom sound

definitions: act of considering one thing to be the same as or equivalent to another
examples: Equating success with wealth is a common but flawed assumption
The professor warned against equating correlation with causation

definitions: imaginary line around Earth's middle, equally distant from North and South poles
examples: Countries near the equator experience hot weather year-round
The ship crossed the equator on its journey to Australia

definitions: person who rides horses, especially as a sport or professional activity
examples: The equestrian competed in three Olympic events
The park has special trails designed for equestrians

definitions: state of physical or mental balance where opposing forces or influences are equal
examples: The ecosystem maintained a delicate equilibrium between predators and prey
Market prices reach equilibrium when supply equals demand

definitions: animal belonging to the horse family, including horses, donkeys, and zebras
examples: The veterinarian specialized in treating equine diseases
The ranch housed various equine species from around the world

definitions: time when the sun crosses the celestial equator, making day and night approximately equal length
examples: The spring equinox marks the beginning of astronomical spring
Ancient cultures held festivals to celebrate the autumn equinox

definitions: act of supplying someone or something with necessary tools, clothing, or equipment
examples: The company focused on equipping workers with proper safety gear
Equipping the laboratory required a substantial financial investment

definitions: condition of being equal or interchangeable in value, function, or meaning
examples: The treaty established equivalence between the two currencies
Scientists debated the equivalence of the two mathematical formulas

definitions: complete destruction or elimination of something, especially a disease or social problem
examples: The global eradication of smallpox was a major medical achievement
Poverty eradication remains a primary goal for many developing nations

definitions: piece of rubber or similar material used to remove pencil or ink marks
examples: The student used an eraser to correct the spelling mistake
She kept several erasers in her pencil case

definitions: act of removing written or recorded material, or the state of being erased
examples: The document showed signs of erasure and rewriting
Cultural erasure occurs when minority histories are ignored or forgotten

definitions: act of building or setting up a structure in an upright position
examples: The crew spent weeks erecting the new office building framework
Erecting the tent in strong wind proved extremely challenging

definitions: process of building or setting up a structure
state of being rigid and upright, especially of body tissue
examples: The erection of the monument took several months to complete
Safety regulations govern the erection of scaffolding on construction sites
The flagpole's erection required a stable concrete base
Medical conditions can affect normal physiological erection
